metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The application of Faraday's Laws and stoichiometry to determine the quantity of galvanic or fuel cell reactant and product, and the current or time required to either use a particular quantity of reactant or produce a particular quantity of product

faraday_constant_definition.name: Faraday's Constant Definition
faraday_constant_definition.correct: Faraday's constant is the amount of electric charge carried by ONE MOLE of electrons, equal to 96 500 coulombs per mole.

96 500 amperes.error: Amperes measure current (charge per second), not total charge.
96 500 amperes.fix: Faraday's constant is in coulombs per mole. Coulombs measure charge; amperes measure current.
96 500 amperes.action: Distinguish units: coulombs = total charge, amperes = charge flow rate.

96 500 volts.error: Volts measure electrical potential, not charge.
96 500 volts.fix: F = 96 500 C mol⁻¹. Volts relate to energy per charge, not the charge itself.
96 500 volts.action: Review SI units: volt = J/C, coulomb = charge, ampere = C/s.

the charge of one electron.error: One electron has charge 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, not 96 500 C.
the charge of one electron.fix: F is charge per MOLE of electrons. Multiply electron charge by Avogadro's number.

6.02 × 10²³ coulombs.error: Confusing Avogadro's number with Faraday's constant.
6.02 × 10²³ coulombs.fix: Avogadro's number is particles per mole. Faraday's constant is coulombs per mole of electrons.
6.02 × 10²³ coulombs.action: F = (charge per electron) × (Avogadro's number) = 96 500 C mol⁻¹.

persistent.gap: You're confusing Faraday's constant with other electrical units.
persistent.action: Write out: F = 96 500 C mol⁻¹ = charge of 1 mole of electrons. Memorise the unit.

electric_charge_unit.name: Electric Charge Unit
electric_charge_unit.correct: Electric charge is measured in coulombs (C). One coulomb equals one ampere flowing for one second.

amperes.error: Amperes measure current (rate of charge flow), not charge itself.
amperes.fix: Charge (Q) is in coulombs. Current (I) is in amperes. Q = It connects them.
amperes.action: Think: amperes = coulombs per second. To get total coulombs, multiply by time.

volts.error: Volts measure potential difference, not charge.
volts.fix: Voltage is energy per unit charge (J/C). Charge itself is measured in coulombs.
volts.action: Three different quantities: charge (C), current (A), voltage (V).

joules.action: Review: Q (charge) in C, I (current) in A, E (energy) in J, V (voltage) in V.

watts.error: Watts measure power (energy per second), not charge.
watts.fix: Power = current × voltage. Charge is measured in coulombs.
watts.action: Watts = J/s = A × V. Coulombs measure total charge passed.

persistent.action: Make a unit table: Q = C, I = A, V = V, P = W, E = J. Practice conversions.

current_definition.name: Current Definition
current_definition.correct: Current is the rate of flow of electric charge. One ampere equals one coulomb per second.

total charge transferred.fix: Current is charge per unit TIME. Current = rate, charge = total amount.
total charge transferred.action: Analogy: current is like flow rate (L/s), charge is like total volume (L).

energy per unit charge.fix: Voltage = J/C. Current = C/s. Different quantities.
energy per unit charge.action: Current measures electron flow rate; voltage measures energy given to electrons.

power output.error: Power = current × voltage, not current alone.
power output.fix: Current is simply charge flow rate (C/s = A).
power output.action: Power involves energy; current only involves charge movement.

resistance to electron flow.fix: Current is the flow itself; resistance opposes the flow.
resistance to electron flow.action: Higher current = more electrons flowing. Higher resistance = harder to flow.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing current from other electrical quantities.
persistent.action: Write: I = Q/t. Current is the RATE. Practice calculating I from Q and t.

charge_formula.name: Charge Formula Q = It
charge_formula.correct: Total charge (Q) equals current (I) multiplied by time (t). Units: C = A × s.

Q = I/t.error: Inverted formula. Division gives rate, not total.
Q = I/t.fix: Charge = current × time. More time = more charge at same current.
Q = I/t.action: Dimensional check: A × s = C/s × s = C. Division would give C/s².

Q = I + t.fix: Q = I × t. Multiplication links the quantities correctly.
Q = I + t.action: Check dimensions: you can only add quantities with the same units.

Q = t/I.error: This gives seconds per ampere, which is meaningless.
Q = t/I.fix: Q = I × t. Total charge increases with both current AND time.
Q = t/I.action: Think: double the current OR double the time → double the charge.

Q = I²t.error: Current is not squared in the charge formula.
Q = I²t.fix: Q = It (no squaring). You may be confusing with power formulas.
Q = I²t.action: Simple multiplication: Q = I × t. No exponents needed.

persistent.gap: You're struggling with the fundamental charge-current-time relationship.
persistent.action: Practice: If I = 2 A for t = 10 s, then Q = 2 × 10 = 20 C. Do 10 examples.

faraday_charge_formula.name: Faraday's Charge Formula
faraday_charge_formula.correct: Total charge (Q) equals moles of electrons multiplied by Faraday's constant. This links chemistry (moles) to physics (charge).

Q = n(e⁻)/F.error: Dividing by F would give a tiny number with wrong units.
Q = n(e⁻)/F.fix: Q = n(e⁻) × F. More moles of electrons = more charge.
Q = n(e⁻)/F.action: Dimensional check: mol × C/mol = C. Division would give mol²/C.

Q = n(e⁻) + F.error: Cannot add moles and coulombs per mole.
Q = n(e⁻) + F.fix: Q = n(e⁻) × F. Multiplication cancels the 'per mole' to give coulombs.
Q = n(e⁻) + F.action: Units: mol × (C/mol) = C. Addition doesn't work with different units.

Q = F/n(e⁻).error: Inverted relationship. More electrons means MORE charge, not less.
Q = F/n(e⁻).fix: Q and n(e⁻) are directly proportional. Q = n(e⁻) × F.
Q = F/n(e⁻).action: Double the electrons → double the charge. Direct proportion means multiply.

Q = n × M × F.error: Molar mass (M) is not part of the charge formula.
Q = n × M × F.fix: Q = n(e⁻) × F only. Mass calculations are separate stoichiometry steps.
Q = n × M × F.action: Keep formulas separate: n = m/M for mass, Q = n(e⁻) × F for charge.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly linking moles of electrons to charge.
persistent.action: Write: Q = n(e⁻) × F = n(e⁻) × 96500. Practice converting moles ↔ coulombs.

electron_mole_ratio.name: Electron Mole Ratio from Half-Equations
electron_mole_ratio.correct: The mole ratio of electrons to reactants/products comes from the balanced half-equation coefficients.

always 1:1.error: The ratio depends on the specific half-equation.
always 1:1.fix: Check the half-equation. Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ gives 2:1 ratio.
always 1:1.action: Write the half-equation. Count electrons. That's your ratio.

equals the atomic number.error: Atomic number is unrelated to electron transfer.
equals the atomic number.fix: The ratio comes from the IONIC CHARGE in the half-equation.
equals the atomic number.action: Zn²⁺ means 2 electrons lost. Cu²⁺ means 2 electrons gained. Use ionic charge.

equals the molar mass.error: Molar mass is for mass-mole conversions, not electron ratios.
equals the molar mass.fix: Electron ratio from half-equation coefficients; molar mass from periodic table.
equals the molar mass.action: Separate the steps: coefficients for ratios, molar mass for n = m/M.

determined by Faraday's constant.error: F converts moles of electrons to charge, doesn't determine ratios.
determined by Faraday's constant.fix: Half-equation gives ratio. F converts moles to coulombs.
determined by Faraday's constant.action: Half-equation: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag (1:1). Then Q = n(e⁻) × F.

persistent.gap: You're not using half-equations to find electron ratios.
persistent.action: Practice: Write half-equations, circle the electrons, determine ratios for 5 different metals.

time_unit_conversion.name: Time Unit Conversion
time_unit_conversion.formula: Time must be in seconds for Q = It
time_unit_conversion.correct: When using Q = It, time must be in SECONDS. Convert minutes/hours: min × 60 = s, hours × 3600 = s.

minutes.error: Minutes must be converted to seconds for Q = It.
minutes.fix: Multiply minutes by 60 to get seconds. 1 min = 60 s.
minutes.action: Always check: Is time in seconds? If not, convert before calculating.

hours.error: Hours must be converted to seconds.
hours.fix: Multiply hours by 3600 (60 × 60) to get seconds.
hours.action: 2 hours = 2 × 3600 = 7200 seconds. Convert BEFORE using Q = It.

any time unit works.error: Using wrong time units gives wrong charge values.
any time unit works.fix: Q = It requires consistent units. Amperes = C/s, so t must be in seconds.
any time unit works.action: Unit check: A = C/s. So Q = A × s = C. Time MUST be seconds.

milliseconds.error: Milliseconds must be converted to seconds.
milliseconds.fix: Divide milliseconds by 1000 to get seconds. 1 ms = 0.001 s.
milliseconds.action: 1000 ms = 1 s. Convert all time units to seconds before calculating.

persistent.gap: You're forgetting to convert time units to seconds.
persistent.action: Make it a habit: FIRST convert all times to seconds, THEN apply formulas.

first_law_understanding.name: Faraday's First Law
first_law_understanding.correct: Faraday's First Law: The mass of substance produced or consumed is directly proportional to the electric charge passed.

mass is inversely proportional to charge.error: Opposite relationship. More charge = more mass produced.
mass is inversely proportional to charge.fix: Direct proportion: double the charge → double the mass deposited.
mass is inversely proportional to charge.action: Think: more electrons flowing = more metal deposited. Direct relationship.

mass is proportional to current only.error: Mass depends on TOTAL charge, not just current.
mass is proportional to current only.fix: Q = It. Mass depends on both current AND time through total charge.
mass is proportional to current only.action: Same mass from 2A for 10s OR 1A for 20s. Both give Q = 20 C.

mass is independent of charge.error: Mass deposited definitely depends on charge passed.
mass is independent of charge.fix: More electrons transferred = more atoms deposited = more mass.
mass is independent of charge.action: Each electron reduces one ion. More electrons = more atoms = more mass.

mass equals charge.error: Mass and charge have different units and aren't equal.
mass equals charge.fix: Mass is PROPORTIONAL to charge, but they're different quantities (g vs C).
mass equals charge.action: m ∝ Q means they increase together, not that m = Q.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the mass-charge relationship.
persistent.action: Memorise: More charge → more electrons → more atoms deposited → more mass.

second_law_understanding.name: Faraday's Second Law
second_law_understanding.correct: Faraday's Second Law: For the same charge, the moles of substance produced is inversely proportional to the ionic charge.

moles proportional to ionic charge.error: It's INVERSE proportion. Higher charge = fewer moles.
moles proportional to ionic charge.fix: Zn²⁺ needs 2e⁻ per ion. Ag⁺ needs 1e⁻. Same electrons deposit more Ag atoms.
moles proportional to ionic charge.action: Same charge: deposits 2 mol Ag (1+) OR 1 mol Zn (2+). Inverse relationship.

ionic charge doesn't affect amount.error: Ionic charge is crucial. Higher charge needs more electrons per atom.
ionic charge doesn't affect amount.fix: Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al needs 3× more electrons than Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag per atom.
ionic charge doesn't affect amount.action: Compare: same charge deposits more atoms of lower-charged ions.

only depends on molar mass.error: Molar mass affects mass, but ionic charge affects moles deposited.
only depends on molar mass.fix: Ionic charge determines electrons per atom; molar mass converts moles to grams.
only depends on molar mass.action: Two separate effects: ionic charge (moles), molar mass (mass per mole).

directly proportional to charge squared.error: No squaring involved. Simple inverse proportion.
directly proportional to charge squared.fix: n ∝ 1/(ionic charge). Double the charge → half the moles.
directly proportional to charge squared.action: 1+ ion: 1 mol per mol e⁻. 2+ ion: 0.5 mol per mol e⁻. Simple inverse.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how ionic charge affects amount deposited.
persistent.action: Calculate moles deposited for same Q with 1+, 2+, and 3+ ions. See the pattern.

calculation_steps.name: Calculation Step Sequence
calculation_steps.correct: Faraday calculation steps: (1) Write half-equation, (2) Find mole ratios, (3) Calculate n(e⁻), (4) Use Q = n(e⁻) × F, (5) Use Q = It.

start with Q = It.error: You need the half-equation first to find electron moles.
start with Q = It.fix: Start with chemistry (half-equation, moles), then convert to electricity.
start with Q = It.action: Order: half-equation → stoichiometry → n(e⁻) → Q → I or t.

skip the half-equation.error: Half-equation gives the essential electron ratio.
skip the half-equation.fix: Without the half-equation, you can't know how many electrons per atom.
skip the half-equation.action: ALWAYS write the half-equation first. It's the link between chemistry and electricity.

directly convert mass to charge.error: Missing the moles step. Must go through moles of electrons.
directly convert mass to charge.fix: mass → moles (n=m/M) → moles of e⁻ (ratio) → charge (Q=nF).
directly convert mass to charge.action: Follow the chain: grams → moles → electron moles → coulombs.

use molar mass in the charge formula.error: Molar mass is for n = m/M, not for Q = n(e⁻) × F.
use molar mass in the charge formula.fix: Keep mass calculations separate from charge calculations.
use molar mass in the charge formula.action: Two separate formulas: n = m/M (mass↔moles), Q = n(e⁻) × F (moles↔charge).

persistent.gap: You're not following the correct sequence of calculation steps.
persistent.action: Write out the 5-step process. Practice on 10 problems, checking each step.

fuel_cell_application.name: Faraday's Laws in Fuel Cells
fuel_cell_application.formula: Same laws apply to continuous reactant supply
fuel_cell_application.correct: Faraday's Laws apply to fuel cells the same way as galvanic cells. The continuous reactant supply means continuous electron flow.

Faraday's Laws don't apply to fuel cells.error: Faraday's Laws apply to ALL electrochemical cells.
Faraday's Laws don't apply to fuel cells.fix: Fuel cells are galvanic cells with external reactant supply. Same electron transfer principles.
Faraday's Laws don't apply to fuel cells.action: Fuel cell = galvanic cell + continuous fuel. Same Faraday calculations.

different constant for fuel cells.error: Faraday's constant is universal for all electron transfers.
different constant for fuel cells.fix: F = 96 500 C mol⁻¹ regardless of cell type. Electrons are electrons.
different constant for fuel cells.action: Same constant, same formulas, same calculations for all electrochemical cells.

fuel cells don't involve electron transf.error: Fuel cells definitely involve electron transfer through external circuit.
fuel cells don't involve electron transf.fix: Fuel oxidised at anode releases electrons; oxygen reduced at cathode accepts electrons.
fuel cells don't involve electron transf.action: Hydrogen fuel cell: H₂ → 2H⁺ + 2e⁻ at anode. Electrons flow through circuit.

only primary cells use Faraday's Laws.error: All electrochemical cells follow Faraday's Laws.
only primary cells use Faraday's Laws.fix: Primary, secondary, and fuel cells all involve quantifiable electron transfer.
only primary cells use Faraday's Laws.action: Faraday's Laws are fundamental. They apply whenever electrons are transferred.

persistent.gap: You don't see fuel cells as following the same electrochemical principles.
persistent.action: Compare galvanic and fuel cell diagrams. Both have anode, cathode, electron flow.

fundamentals.title: Understanding Faraday's Laws
fundamentals.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of Faraday's fundamental concepts.

sentences.text: Faraday's constant (F) represents the amount of {{d1}} carried by one {{d2}} of electrons, and has a value of {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Think about what quantity F measures - is it a rate or a total amount?

d2.tooltip: F converts between chemistry units (moles) and physics units (charge)

d3.tooltip: The unit includes coulombs per mole

sentences.text: Electric charge is measured in {{d4}}, while the rate of charge flow (current) is measured in {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: This unit measures total charge, not charge per second

d5.tooltip: Current is charge per unit time - which unit measures this?

sentences.text: Faraday's First Law states that the mass of substance produced at an electrode is {{d6}} proportional to the {{d7}} passed through the cell.

d6.tooltip: More charge means more electrons, which deposits more mass

d7.tooltip: The law relates mass to the TOTAL charge, not the rate of charge flow

formulas.title: Key Formulas in Faraday's Laws
formulas.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of the essential formulas.

sentences.text: The total charge (Q) flowing through a circuit can be calculated using Q = {{d1}}, where I is current in amperes and t is time in {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Total charge equals current multiplied by time

d2.tooltip: Since ampere = C/s, time must be in seconds for units to work

sentences.text: The relationship between moles of electrons and charge is given by Q = {{d3}}, which shows that charge is {{d4}} proportional to moles of electrons.

d3.tooltip: Moles of electrons times Faraday's constant gives charge

d4.tooltip: More moles of electrons means more charge

sentences.text: According to Faraday's Second Law, for the same amount of charge, the moles of metal deposited is {{d5}} proportional to the {{d6}} on the ion.

d5.tooltip: Higher charged ions need more electrons per atom

d6.tooltip: The charge on the ion determines electrons needed per atom

stoichiometry.title: Linking Stoichiometry to Electrochemistry
stoichiometry.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to connect stoichiometry concepts with Faraday's Laws.

sentences.text: The mole ratio between electrons and the substance being oxidised or reduced is determined from the balanced {{d1}}.

d1.tooltip: This type of equation shows electrons explicitly

sentences.text: For the reduction Ag⁺(aq) + e⁻ → Ag(s), the mole ratio of electrons to silver atoms is {{d2}}, meaning {{d3}} mole of electrons deposits {{d4}} mole of silver.

d2.tooltip: Count the electrons in the half-equation

d3.tooltip: Read the coefficient in front of e⁻ in the half-equation

d4.tooltip: Read the coefficient in front of Ag in the half-equation

sentences.text: For the oxidation Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻, {{d5}} moles of electrons are released for every {{d6}} mole of zinc that reacts.

d5.tooltip: Look at the coefficient in front of e⁻

d6.tooltip: Look at the coefficient in front of Zn

calculations.title: Problem-Solving Approach
calculations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand the calculation process.

sentences.text: The first step in a Faraday calculation is to write the {{d1}} to determine the {{d2}} between electrons and the substance.

d1.tooltip: This equation shows electrons explicitly and gives you the ratio

d2.tooltip: The ratio from coefficients links substance to electrons

sentences.text: To convert between mass and moles, use the formula n = {{d3}}, then use stoichiometry to find {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Moles equals mass divided by molar mass

d4.tooltip: You need moles of electrons to then calculate charge

sentences.text: Faraday's Laws apply equally to galvanic cells and {{d5}} because both involve {{d6}} through an external circuit.

d5.tooltip: These cells use continuous external fuel supply

d6.tooltip: The fundamental process in all electrochemical cells

fundamentals.title: Applying Faraday's Fundamentals
fundamentals.instructions: Apply your understanding of Faraday's Laws to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When 2 moles of electrons flow through a cell, the total charge transferred is {{d1}} × {{d2}} = {{d3}} C.

d1.tooltip: How many moles of electrons are flowing?

d2.tooltip: What is Faraday's constant in C mol⁻¹?

sentences.text: If a cell operates at 5.0 A for 30 minutes, the time must first be converted to {{d4}} seconds, giving a total charge of {{d5}} C.

d4.tooltip: Multiply minutes by 60 to get seconds

sentences.text: One ampere is defined as one {{d6}} of charge flowing per {{d7}}, which is why time must be in seconds when using Q = It.

d6.tooltip: Current is charge per time, so 1 A = 1 ? per second

d7.tooltip: The base SI unit for time

formulas.title: Working with Faraday's Formulas
formulas.instructions: Apply the formulas to solve these problems.

sentences.text: To find how long it takes to deposit a certain mass, first calculate moles of substance, then moles of {{d1}}, then charge, and finally rearrange Q = It to find t = {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: The charge formula uses moles of electrons

sentences.text: The reduction Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → Cu(s) shows that depositing 0.5 mol of copper requires {{d3}} mol of electrons, which equals {{d4}} C.

d3.tooltip: The ratio is 2 electrons per 1 copper, so 0.5 mol Cu needs...

sentences.text: If the same charge is passed through cells containing Ag⁺ and Cu²⁺ ions, {{d5}} moles of silver will be deposited compared to copper because silver ions have a {{d6}} charge.

d5.tooltip: Lower charged ions need fewer electrons per atom

stoichiometry.title: Stoichiometry in Action
stoichiometry.instructions: Apply stoichiometry principles to electrochemical calculations.

sentences.text: In a hydrogen fuel cell, the anode reaction 2H₂ → 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ shows that each mole of H₂ releases {{d1}} moles of electrons.

d1.tooltip: The ratio is 4 electrons per 2 H₂ molecules, so per 1 H₂...

sentences.text: To deposit 3.24 g of silver (M = 108 g mol⁻¹), first calculate n(Ag) = {{d2}} mol, then since the ratio is 1:1, n(e⁻) = {{d3}} mol.

d3.tooltip: For Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag, the ratio is 1:1

sentences.text: The oxidation reaction Al(s) → Al³⁺(aq) + 3e⁻ means that {{d4}} mol of electrons are released when 27 g (1 mol) of aluminium {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Count the electrons in the half-equation

d5.tooltip: Electrons are being released (lost) in this reaction

sentences.text: A galvanic cell runs at 2.5 A. To deposit 0.050 mol of a metal from M²⁺ ions, you need {{d1}} mol of electrons, which is {{d2}} C, requiring {{d3}} seconds.
In a fuel cell producing 500 A for 2 hours, the charge is {{d4}} C, which corresponds to {{d5}} mol of electrons.

fundamentals.title: Mastering Faraday's Fundamentals
fundamentals.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of Faraday's Laws concepts.

sentences.text: A common error is confusing current ({{d1}}) with charge ({{d2}}). Current is the {{d3}} of charge flow, while charge is the total amount transferred.

d1.tooltip: The unit for rate of charge flow

d3.tooltip: Current is charge per unit time

sentences.text: Faraday's constant (96 500 C mol⁻¹) can be derived by multiplying the charge on one electron ({{d4}} C) by {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: The charge of a single electron in coulombs

d5.tooltip: The number of particles in one mole

sentences.text: Both galvanic cells and fuel cells follow Faraday's Laws because they both involve {{d6}} reactions where electrons flow through {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: What type of reaction powers these cells?

d7.tooltip: Where do electrons flow to do useful work?

formulas.title: Formula Mastery
formulas.instructions: Show complete understanding of how the formulas connect.

sentences.text: The two key formulas Q = It and Q = n(e⁻) × F can be combined to give n(e⁻) = {{d1}}, linking {{d2}} directly to moles of electrons.

d1.tooltip: Substitute Q = It into Q = n(e⁻) × F and solve for n(e⁻)

d2.tooltip: What quantities are I and t?

sentences.text: When solving for current, rearrange Q = It to I = Q/t. If 0.02 mol of electrons flow in 500 s, I = {{d3}}/500 = {{d4}} A.
A student incorrectly used Q = I/t instead of Q = I × t. This error would give a result in {{d5}} instead of coulombs, which is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What units do you get from dividing amperes by seconds?

d6.tooltip: A/s is not a standard physical quantity

sentences.text: Comparing Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag with Ni²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Ni: passing 96 500 C deposits {{d1}} mol Ag but only {{d2}} mol Ni.

d1.tooltip: 96 500 C = 1 mol e⁻. For Ag⁺, ratio is 1:1

d2.tooltip: For Ni²⁺, ratio is 2:1, so 1 mol e⁻ gives 0.5 mol Ni

sentences.text: In the hydrogen fuel cell reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, the electrons flow from the {{d3}} where hydrogen is {{d4}} to the {{d5}} where oxygen is {{d6}}.
A fuel cell operates at 10 A for 5 hours. The hydrogen consumed can be found by: Q = {{d1}} C, n(e⁻) = {{d2}} mol, and since 2e⁻ per H₂, n(H₂) = {{d3}} mol.

d3.tooltip: 2 mol e⁻ per 1 mol H₂, so divide by 2

sentences.text: To deposit 5.0 g of copper (M = 63.5 g mol⁻¹) using a 2.0 A current: n(Cu) = {{d4}} mol, n(e⁻) = {{d5}} mol, Q = {{d6}} C, t = {{d7}} s.

faraday_constant_definition.title: Faraday's Constant
faraday_constant_definition.content: Faraday's constant (F) is the amount of electric charge carried by one mole of electrons. It equals 96 500 coulombs per mole. This value comes from multiplying the charge on a single electron (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) by Avogadro's number (6.02 × 10²³). Faraday's constant is the bridge between chemistry (moles) and physics (charge).
keyPoints: Represents charge of 1 mole of electrons
Same value for all electrochemical cells

electric_charge_unit.title: Electric Charge
electric_charge_unit.content: Electric charge (Q) is measured in coulombs (C). One coulomb is the amount of charge that passes when one ampere of current flows for one second. In electrochemistry, charge tells us the total number of electrons that have flowed, which connects directly to the amount of substance reacted or produced.

current_definition.title: Electric Current
current_definition.content: Current (I) is the rate of flow of electric charge, measured in amperes (A). One ampere equals one coulomb per second (1 A = 1 C s⁻¹). Current tells us how fast electrons are flowing, not how many total electrons have passed. Higher current means more product formed per unit time.
keyPoints: Rate of electron flow, not total electrons

charge_formula.title: The Charge Formula Q = It
charge_formula.content: The total charge (Q) equals current (I) multiplied by time (t). This formula requires time in seconds because the ampere is defined as coulombs per second. If time is given in minutes or hours, convert to seconds first: minutes × 60, hours × 3600.
keyPoints: Rearrange for I = Q/t or t = Q/I

faraday_charge_formula.title: Linking Moles to Charge
faraday_charge_formula.content: The formula Q = n(e⁻) × F connects chemistry to electricity. Total charge equals moles of electrons multiplied by Faraday's constant. This allows conversion between moles (from stoichiometry) and coulombs (from electrical measurements).
keyPoints: Converts moles of electrons to coulombs
Central formula linking chemistry and electricity

electron_mole_ratio.title: Electron Mole Ratios
electron_mole_ratio.content: The mole ratio between electrons and substances comes from balanced half-equations. For example, Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag has a 1:1 ratio, while Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu has a 2:1 ratio. This ratio is essential for converting between moles of substance and moles of electrons in Faraday calculations.

time_unit_conversion.title: Time Unit Conversions
time_unit_conversion.content: When using Q = It, time must be in seconds because amperes are defined as coulombs per second. Always convert before calculating: multiply minutes by 60, multiply hours by 3600. Failing to convert is a common source of errors in Faraday calculations.
keyPoints: Q = It requires time in seconds

first_law_understanding.title: Faraday's First Law
first_law_understanding.content: Faraday's First Law states that the mass of substance produced or consumed at an electrode is directly proportional to the electric charge passed. This means doubling the charge doubles the mass deposited. The law connects the physical quantity (charge) to the chemical outcome (mass).

second_law_understanding.title: Faraday's Second Law
second_law_understanding.content: Faraday's Second Law states that for the same amount of charge, the moles of substance deposited is inversely proportional to the ionic charge. Ions with higher charges need more electrons per atom, so fewer atoms are deposited. For example, 1 mole of electrons deposits 1 mol Ag⁺ but only 0.5 mol Cu²⁺.
keyPoints: Higher charge = fewer moles per electron
Same charge: more Ag⁺ deposited than Cu²⁺

calculation_steps.title: Calculation Step Sequence
calculation_steps.content: Faraday calculations follow a specific sequence: (1) Write the half-equation to find electron ratios, (2) Convert mass to moles using n = m/M, (3) Use stoichiometry to find moles of electrons, (4) Convert to charge using Q = n(e⁻) × F, (5) Use Q = It to find current or time.
keyPoints: Step 5: Find current or time (Q = It)

fuel_cell_application.title: Faraday's Laws in Fuel Cells
fuel_cell_application.content: Faraday's Laws apply to fuel cells just as they do to other galvanic cells. Fuel cells continuously supply reactants (like hydrogen and oxygen), but the electron transfer follows the same principles. The same formulas (Q = It, Q = nF) are used to calculate reactant consumption and product formation.
keyPoints: Same laws for all electrochemical cells
Fuel cells have continuous reactant supply
